meta.article_title: April 1, 2024 - What Makes a Great Doubles Partnership?

what_makes_a_great_doubles_partnership.probleme: Doubles team underperforms due to weak partnership qualities.

debutant: Adopt a team-first mindset; adjust your game to set up your partner’s strengths.
Build doubles experience and play together often.
Ensure compatible personalities and communicate about serves, receives, and movement.
Be patient with your partner; avoid squabbling.
intermediaire: Assess style compatibility and make adjustments (e.g., defender playing more aggressively; learn to handle attacks).
Develop tactical flexibility such as learning to push short in doubles even if you push long in singles.
Commit to learning doubles-specific skills (short serves from right court, short pushes, doubles footwork).
avance: Regularly evaluate the partnership across the ten components and address weakest areas first.

erreurs_a_eviter: Refusing to adjust personal game for team benefit.
Letting frustration show when partner errs.

lets_talk_about_shoes.probleme: Choosing shoes that hinder side-to-side mobility or lack needed support.
lets_talk_about_shoes.diagnostic: Thin-soled TT shoes improve lateral movement but offer less support; surface (cement vs wood/rubberized) changes support needs.
causes_communes: Wearing running shoes designed for forward motion.
Using one shoe type regardless of age, surface, or event.

debutant: Prioritize shoes that allow side-to-side movement and floor grip, especially at the balls of the feet.
intermediaire: Balance mobility and support based on age and playing surface; use more support on cement.
Adopt two-shoe strategy: supportive pair for practice; thinner, more mobile pair near and during tournaments.
avance: Match shoe grip to venue; newer shoes may help on slightly slippery floors.

erreurs_a_eviter: Using running shoes for table tennis.
Ignoring surface grippiness and support needs.

meta.article_title: March 11, 2024 - The Four Types of Defense

the_four_types_of_defense.probleme: Players lack a complete defensive toolkit.
the_four_types_of_defense.diagnostic: Defense has four main forms: blocking, chopping, fishing/lobbing, and defensive counterlooping; each has situational value.

debutant: Develop solid blocking on both sides so you rarely miss unless the opponent forces it.
intermediaire: Learn basic chops for specific situations (e.g., wide backhand when out of position).
Add fishing and lobbing as situational defenses without overusing them.
avance: Adopt defensive counterlooping on the forehand as a primary defensive option when a step off the table, avoiding over-aggression off the bounce.

exercices_complementaires.description: Play games trying to win using pushes and blocks to ingrain a rock-solid blocking mindset.

erreurs_a_eviter: Getting disgusted by a missed block instead of treating it as a surprise to correct.
Fishing or lobbing when not necessary.

meta.article_title: March 4, 2024 - The Definition of Insanity and Its Table Tennis Implications

definition_of_insanity_table_tennis_impl.probleme: Stagnant improvement and inconsistent performance habits.
definition_of_insanity_table_tennis_impl.diagnostic: Doing the same training without results, or changing proven preparation routines and expecting the same performance.

debutant: If a part of your game isn’t improving, change how you train that part and understand that match wins may lag behind skill gains.
intermediaire: Identify what you did before your best performances (nutrition, warm-up, mental routine) and repeat that preparation consistently.
avance: Create a repeatable pre-match routine that triggers focus, then iteratively refine training methods when progress stalls.

erreurs_a_eviter: Expecting different results from unchanged training.
Abandoning effective routines and expecting unchanged outcomes.

be_the_lawnmower.probleme: Players aim to upset stronger opponents without first mastering dominance skills.
be_the_lawnmower.diagnostic: Domination skills (serve/receive, attacks, defense, consistency) are best developed by learning to win easily against weaker players in many ways.

debutant: In practice vs weaker players, avoid relying solely on best serves; use simple short backspin or no-spin to start rallies and develop opening loops.
intermediaire: Systematically practice dominating with multiple aspects (e.g., backhand, blocking) rather than just usual strengths.
avance: In serious matches vs weaker opponents, reintroduce best weapons to fully dominate after practicing broad dominance in training.

erreurs_a_eviter: Over-relying on serves against weaker players and being unprepared when stronger opponents neutralize them.

meta.article_title: February 19, 2024 - The Laziness of Simple Serves

the_laziness_of_simple_serves.probleme: Players rely on simple, non-deceptive serves and fall behind tactically.
the_laziness_of_simple_serves.diagnostic: Opponents develop nasty, deceptive serves while the player only serves to start the rally.

debutant: Learn to vary between heavy backspin and true no-spin with identical motions (fine wrist graze vs contact near handle).
intermediaire: Practice deception and spin production extensively so serves that look simple are actually tricky.
When facing effective serves, ask opponents how they execute them, learn the motion, and practice it; understanding a serve aids returning it.
avance: Aim for serves that are hard to read rather than merely safe to put in play.

erreurs_a_eviter: Dismissing strong servers instead of developing comparable serving skill.
Telegraphing spin differences with clearly different motions.

meta.article_title: February 12, 2024 - Learn From Your Easy Wins and Bad Losses

learn_from_easy_wins_and_bad_losses.probleme: Players fail to analyze blowout matches for improvement.
learn_from_easy_wins_and_bad_losses.diagnostic: Easy wins and lopsided losses reveal dominant elements and major weaknesses.

debutant: After a blowout win, identify what worked extremely well and consider building it to work versus stronger players.
intermediaire: After a blowout loss, determine if opponent’s serves, serve-returns, rally dominance, or put-aways caused the result and address the specific area.
avance: Practice returning troublesome serves (possibly by learning them yourself) and redesign serve/follow-up patterns to regain initiative.

erreurs_a_eviter: Confusing rally superiority with simply winning initiative at the start of points.
